questions.prompt: For a real periodic signal x(t), the FS coefficients satisfy:
questions.explanation: Real signals have conjugate symmetry: X_{−k} = X_k*. This means the real part of X_k is even and the imaginary part is odd. The magnitude is even (|X_{−k}| = |X_k|) and the phase is odd (∠X_{−k} = −∠X_k).

questions.prompt: If x(t) is real and even, then X_k is:
options: C) Complex with equal real and imaginary parts
questions.explanation: Real: X_{−k} = X_k*. Even: X_{−k} = X_k. Combining: X_k* = X_k, so X_k is real. Also X_k = X_{−k}, so X_k is an even function of k. The square pulse (centred) is a perfect example.

questions.prompt: If x(t) is real and odd, then X_k is:
options: B) Purely imaginary and odd, with X₀ = 0
questions.explanation: Real: X_{−k} = X_k*. Odd: X_{−k} = −X_k. Together: X_k* = −X_k → X_k is purely imaginary. Also X_k = −X_{−k} (odd). For k=0: X₀ = −X₀ → X₀ = 0 (odd functions have zero average).
From X_{−k} = X_k*: |X_{−k}| = |X_k*| = |X_k|. The magnitude spectrum is always even symmetric for real signals. You only need to plot the positive-k half.
From X_{−k} = X_k*: ∠X_{−k} = ∠(X_k*) = −∠X_k. The phase spectrum is odd (anti-symmetric about k=0). For real, even signals the phase is zero everywhere (X_k is real).

questions.prompt: The signal sin(ω₀t) is real and odd. Its FS coefficient X₀ is:
questions.explanation: For odd signals, X₀ = 0. The average of sin(ω₀t) over one period is zero — the positive and negative halves cancel exactly.

questions.prompt: If you compute X_k for a real signal and find |X₃| ≠ |X_{−3}|, you should:
options: A) Accept the result — conjugate symmetry doesn't apply
B) Recheck your computation — this violates conjugate symmetry
questions.explanation: For real signals, |X_{−k}| must equal |X_k|. If your computation gives |X₃| ≠ |X_{−3}|, there's an error somewhere. Use symmetry as a built-in verification tool.

questions.prompt: The even part of a real signal x(t) is:
questions.explanation: Any signal can be decomposed as x(t) = x_e(t) + x_o(t), where x_e(t) = [x(t)+x(−t)]/2 is the even part and x_o(t) = [x(t)−x(−t)]/2 is the odd part. The even part contributes the real part of X_k; the odd part contributes the imaginary part.

questions.prompt: For an even signal, the FS integral can be simplified to:
questions.explanation: For even x(t), the product x(t)·sin(kω₀t) is odd (even × odd = odd) and integrates to zero over a symmetric interval. Only the cosine part survives: X_k = (2/T₀)∫₀^{T₀/2} x(t)cos(kω₀t) dt — halving the integration work.

questions.prompt: A purely imaginary signal jg(t) (where g(t) is real) has FS coefficients satisfying:
questions.explanation: If x(t) = jg(t) where g is real, then x(t)* = −jg(t) = −x(t). So X_k* = X_{−k}* → using x* = −x we get X_{−k} = −X_k*. This is anti-conjugate symmetry.
